author: Mini Muringatheri
text:
The laboratory tests of actor Kalabhavan Mani’s internal organs have revealed the presence of pesticide residue.

The viscera report from the Regional Chemical Examiner’s Laboratory, Kakkanad, has indicated the presence of Chlorpyrifose, a pesticide used in plants. The pesticide is used to increase the potency of spurious liquor, the report said.

The laboratory report also indicated the presence of methanol and ethanol content in the body of the Malayalam actor.

Kalabhavan Mani was admitted in an unconscious state to a private hospital in Kochi on March 5. He died on March 6.

Following the release of the laboratory reports, Kalabhavan Mani’s relatives have sought a high-level investigation into the actor’s death.

His brother, R.L.V. Ramakrishnan, has demanded that a murder case be registered against the actor’s friends who were with him at ‘Paddy,’ Mani’s private farmhouse, on March 5.

“The laboratory findings are shocking. There is some mystery behind the death. It is suspicious how the pesticide content and methanol were found in the body. Why was methanol content not found in any other person who consumed alcohol with him? Nobody is giving a convincing answer about what Mani had consumed. Doctors indicated that such pesticide content and methanol are usually found in hooch. Who gave him hooch?” he said.

Mr. Ramakrishnan alleged that Mani’s friends used to give him alcohol even after his relatives had expressed their protest.

Relatives seek expert investigation
title: Pesticide residue found in Mani’s body
